prior_works.title: PGDrive: Procedural Generation of Driving Scenarios
prior_works.role: Procedural/compositional simulator that parameterizes road networks and scenarios to yield diverse, endlessly generated driving environments for RL and planning.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban generalizes PGDrive’s parameterized, compositional world generation from road-centric driving to full urban micromobility and shared sidewalk spaces with richer agent types and interactions.

prior_works.title: CARLA: An Open Urban Driving Simulator
prior_works.authors: Alexey Dosovitskiy, German Ros, Felipe Codevilla, Antonio M. López, Vladlen Koltun
prior_works.role: High-fidelity, open urban driving simulator with pedestrians, sensors, weather, and RL-friendly APIs widely used for autonomy evaluation.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban adopts CARLA-like principles of sensor realism and interactive urban scenes but reorients them toward sidewalk-scale micromobility and compositional scene synthesis rather than fixed city maps.

prior_works.title: Habitat: A Platform for Embodied AI Research
prior_works.authors: Manolis Savva, Abhishek Kadian, Oleksandr Maksymets, et al.
prior_works.role: Scalable, fast embodied AI simulation and benchmarking emphasizing large-scale generalization and reproducibility.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban embraces Habitat’s design tenets of fast, scalable embodied simulation and generalization-focused evaluation, extending them to outdoor urban micromobility settings.

prior_works.title: Gibson Env: Real-World Perception for Embodied Agents
prior_works.authors: Fei Xia, Amir R. Zamir, Zhiyang He, Alexander Sax, Jitendra Malik, Silvio Savarese
prior_works.role: Photorealistic embodied simulation drawn from real scans, enabling perception-driven navigation and interaction.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban draws on Gibson’s emphasis on perceptual realism to keep procedurally composed urban scenes visually and physically plausible for embodied micromobility agents.

prior_works.title: SUMO: Simulation of Urban MObility
prior_works.authors: Daniel Krajzewicz, Jakob Erdmann, Michael Behrisch, Laura Bieker
prior_works.role: Open-source microscopic traffic simulator supporting heterogeneous agents (cars, pedestrians, bikes) on complex urban networks.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban borrows SUMO’s microsimulation concepts to coordinate heterogeneous urban flows, integrating pedestrians and vulnerable road users alongside mobile robots at sidewalk scale.

prior_works.title: Optimal Reciprocal Collision Avoidance (ORCA) for Multiple Agents
prior_works.authors: Jur van den Berg, Stephen J. Guy, Ming Lin, Dinesh Manocha
prior_works.role: Real-time multi-agent collision avoidance method widely used for robot and crowd simulations.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban leverages ORCA-style reciprocal collision avoidance as a baseline behavior model for dense sidewalk and plaza interactions among micromobility agents and pedestrians.

prior_works.title: Social Force Model for Pedestrian Dynamics
prior_works.role: Foundational model for realistic pedestrian motion and interaction in crowds.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MetaUrban incorporates Social-Force-inspired pedestrian behaviors to create realistic, interactive sidewalk crowds that stress-test micromobility policies.

synthesis_narrative: MetaUrban’s core contribution is a compositional, at-scale simulation platform tailored to urban micromobility, capable of generating effectively infinite, interactive scenes populated by diverse agents. Its design directly builds on procedural composition pioneered by PGDrive, extending parameterized road and scenario generation to include sidewalks, plazas, and vulnerable road users, thus shifting the focus from car-only driving to shared public spaces. From CARLA, MetaUrban inherits the impetus for high-fidelity perception, rich actuation/sensor modeling, and interactive urban assets, while explicitly re-scoping those capabilities to the sidewalk regime. The scalability, speed, and generalization-centric ethos of Habitat inform MetaUrban’s emphasis on large-scale training and evaluation, enabling robust assessment of policy generalization across procedurally varied cities. Gibson’s focus on perceptual realism further motivates MetaUrban’s attention to visual and physical plausibility, ensuring procedurally composed scenes remain credible for embodied agents. To model the complex multi-agent dynamics characteristic of urban public spaces, MetaUrban draws on SUMO’s microsimulation principles for heterogeneous flows, and adopts classic interaction models—ORCA for reciprocal, real-time collision avoidance and the Social Force model for pedestrian dynamics—to populate environments with realistic human and VRU behaviors. Together, these strands converge in MetaUrban: a platform that unifies scalable, compositional scene generation with credible multi-agent interactions and embodied sensing, purpose-built to evaluate safety and generalization of AI-driven micromobility.
